WikiLeaks, which last month published nearly 20,000 Democratic National Committee emails stolen by hackers, flagged the suspension of the Guccifer 2.0 account.

“You may not publish or post other people’s private and confidential information, such as credit card numbers, street address, or Social Security/National Identity numbers, without their express authorization and permission,” Twitter says.

The hacker, who goes by the pseudonym Guccifer 2.0 and is believed to be somehow connected to the Russian government, had recently invited reporters to reach out through Twitter to obtain additional hacked documents.
Twitter has suspended the account of the computer hacker who on Friday published a spreadsheet purported to contain personal contact information for nearly 200 Democratic members of Congress.
Many other Twitter users published links to the documents as well as screen shots of the spreadsheet containing the Democratic lawmakers’ personal contact information.
Guccifer 2.0’s latest document dump is of records stolen from the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC), the campaign arm of House Democrats.
Last month, the user of Guccifer 2.0’s Twitter account invited this reporter to contact them through direct message in order to obtain hacked documents.
Several other officials were forced out as well because some of their email exchanges showed them appearing to plot against Bernie Sanders.
But the publication of other people’s private and confidential information is against the site’s rules, its website states.
Guccifer 2.0 has recently invited journalists to reach out through Twitter in order to obtain hacked documents.
The documents include the email and physical addresses of nearly 200 Democratic members of Congress.
Guccifer 2.0 published links on Twitter to its latest release of the personal Democratic documents.
The company did not respond to The Daily Caller’s request for comment about the suspension.
That release led to the resignation of Florida Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz as DNC chair.
Guccifer 2.0 published some DNC information on a WordPress website starting in June.
The hacker also published lists of passwords used by DCCC staffers.
Twitter’s rationale for the suspension is not immediately clear.
The hacker shared other documents with several news outlets.
